intro: Seseli libanotis var. athamantoides, commonly known as the Lebanon sesame or Athamantoides sesame, is a perennial herb native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in mountainous areas. Due to its ornamental value and historical significance, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
